substories.title: Departure from Lisbon
substories.description: On July 8, 1497, Vasco da Gama set sail from Lisbon with four ships, interpreters, and stone pillars called padrões to mark discovery. It marked the beginning of a bold voyage into the unknown.

substories.title: Passing the Canary Islands
substories.description: By July 15, 1497, the fleet passed the Canary Islands, catching the Atlantic winds as they journeyed southward into uncharted waters.

substories.title: Reaching Cape Verde
substories.description: On July 26, 1497, the fleet reached São Tiago in Cape Verde. They stayed until August 3, restocking supplies and preparing for the long voyage ahead.

substories.title: South Atlantic Detour
substories.description: In August 1497, da Gama led the fleet deep into the South Atlantic to avoid the Gulf of Guinea’s currents, sailing through vast open seas until early November.

substories.title: Santa Helena Bay
substories.description: On November 7, 1497, the fleet finally spotted land again at Santa Helena Bay in South Africa after months at sea.

substories.title: Rounding the Cape
substories.description: On November 22, 1497, the fleet rounded the stormy Cape of Good Hope, battling powerful winds and currents to continue eastward.

substories.title: Anchoring at Mossel Bay
substories.description: Three days later, on November 25, 1497, the fleet anchored at Mossel Bay, where they erected a padrão and dismantled the storeship.

substories.title: The Natal Coast
substories.description: On December 25, 1497, da Gama reached the southeastern African coast and named it 'Natal' in honor of Christmas Day.

substories.title: Rest at Rio do Cobre
substories.description: On January 11, 1498, the fleet stopped near a small river they named Rio do Cobre, resting for five days along the southeastern coast of Africa.

substories.title: River of Good Omens
substories.description: By January 25, 1498, the fleet reached the Quelimane River, which they called the River of Good Omens, and stayed for nearly a month while recovering from scurvy.

substories.title: The Island of Mozambique
substories.description: On March 2, 1498, the fleet arrived at the Island of Mozambique, where locals mistook the Portuguese for Muslims and da Gama secured pilots for the next leg of the journey.

substories.title: Arrival at Mombasa
substories.description: On April 7, 1498, the fleet reached the port of Mombasa, but the city was hostile, and da Gama stayed only briefly before moving on.

substories.title: A Pilot from Malindi
substories.description: On April 14, 1498, da Gama arrived at Malindi, where he secured a skilled Gujarati pilot who knew the sea route to India.

substories.title: Crossing the Indian Ocean
substories.description: With their new pilot, the fleet began a 23-day journey across the Indian Ocean on April 25, 1498, heading into unfamiliar and challenging waters.

substories.title: Arrival at Calicut
substories.description: On May 20, 1498, da Gama finally reached Calicut on the Indian coast. Though a padrão was erected to mark the achievement, the diplomatic mission faced failure due to misunderstandings and weak gifts.
